p: Out of the six studies on integrated care with OAT [ 13– 15, 30– 32], only two studies found an effect of the integrated care intervention [ 31, 32]. Hospitalized patients infected with TB receiving OAT in an integrated care setting showed a significant improvement on TB treatment completion (90% versus 74%, p = 0.03) and the adherence to TB medication (97% versus 86%; p < 0.01) after controlling for death and dropouts [ 31]. Additionally, Batki et al. (2002) found a significant effect on HIV suppression when integrating directly administrated OAT and antiretroviral therapy (ART) against HIV, counseling, psychiatric treatment and social works were compared to standard routine care in an outpatient clinic in people with SUD (60% versus 13%; p < 0.01) [ 32]. The remaining four studies showed no significant effect of integrated care on HIV suppression or achievement of HCV SVR when OAT and antiviral therapy against HIV or HCV were integrated at outpatient clinics [ 13– 15, 30].
